body: Add "Blocked" to wait #5149
Something is wrong. A lot merged changes are shown up in this PR. Can you please rebase?

@PaulHigin I believe I've address all of your feedback.
@daxian-dbw I've fixed the commit list.

> The hash code is used in-lieu of logging the long commit id with every log message. Instead, I log an initial entry containing the full commit id and the associated hash. Subsequent entries contain on the hash. SysLogProvider has a comment block at the beginning that illustrates its usage.

"GetHashCode" on the same string text value will return different hash value in different processes. Would that cause any confusion?

@daxian-dbw The intent is to be able to identify the the full commit id from the hash.  There's currently, as far as I can tell, no built-in way to get a stable string hash.  We'd have to look to one of the security hashing algorithms or provide a modified one of our own; something that doesn't change per process or per build.

If we go that route, we should document it because I expect consumers to take a dependency on specific values.
Git commit id is already a hash - can we use it?

@iSazonov The Git commit id is something like this: v6.0.0-beta.8-67-gca2630a3dea6420a3cd3914c84a74c1c45311f54
I'm trying to avoid logging that with every log record.
SHA is only `ca2630a3dea6420a3cd3914c84a74c1c45311f54` and we can use first 7 chars.
@iSazonov Is this just a general comment or are you requesting it be changed?
It is a suggestion. I don't know how much this hash is good for the logging. It seems good.
Git accepts any number of characters from the hash as long as it's unambiguous.  Typically, the first 7 characters is sufficient, but sometimes you have to use more if there's a collision.

@daxian-dbw, @iSazonov, @lzybkr : Any additional comments?

@daxian-dbw Note that this PR depends on https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/5151.
@daxian-dbw  This is dependent on https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/5231.
@iSazonov and @lzybkr: let me know if you have any more comments.
LGTM.
@dantraMSFT The macbook is not available today, so I probably cannot publish a new package for libspl today. I will check with @TravisEz13 to see if he can build the libspl binary for osx.
@dantraMSFT The new libpsl package `libpsl 6.0.0-beta.8` has been published (https://powershell.myget.org/feed/powershell-core/package/nuget/libpsl). Can you please try and see if it works?
@lzybkr Can you please take another look and see if you have further comments?
@daxian-dbw I'm producing a build to test the libpsl package now.

I'm done reviewing this - so no more comments. I tried taking another look, but I'm on a smaller screen for the next couple weeks and it's getting annoying to review this way, so I'll just trust @dantraMSFT on the updates.
@dantraMSFT I just noticed that there are no tests in this PR. Are you planning to add tests later?
NOTE: This PR is dependent on https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/5310 as well as republishing the nugget package for libpsl-native.
#5310 has been merged. Need to update the libpsl nuget package to include the binary with the new changes.

The new libpsl nuget package has been published to powershell-core feed.
I also restarted the Travis CI builds.
@daxian-dbw I've verified the package on Ubuntu 14.04, Rasberry PI, and Mac 10.12. My 16.04 system is currently hosed.
